DataElement.preferredDefinition: A desciptor related to the kind of specimen submitted for the judgment or consideration of others.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Any material sample taken from a biological entity for testing, diagnostic, propagation, treatment or research purposes, including a sample obtained from a living organism or taken from the biological object after halting of all its life functions. Biospecimen can contain one or more components including but not limited to cellular molecules, cells, tissues, organs, body fluids, embryos, and body excretory products._Something submitted for the judgment or consideration of others._A written or verbal account, representation, statement, or explanation of something.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Any material sample taken from a biological entity for testing, diagnostic, propagation, treatment or research purposes, including a sample obtained from a living organism or taken from the biological object after halting of all its life functions. ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Marked or discolored by foreign material.: The removal of a tissue sample using a needle with a relatively large diameter, for microscopic examination.

Concepts.definition: Marked or discolored by foreign material.
The removal of a tissue sample using a needle with a relatively large diameter, for microscopic examination.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Marked or discolored by foreign material.: A biopsy involving the removal of a core tissue containing bone spicules and hematopoietic elements embedded in the marrow stroma.  This procedure is done in the hip area mainly for the diagnosis and evaluation of neoplastic and non-neoplastic hematopoietic disorders (e.g. anemias, leukemias, lymphomas) and the evaluation of the spread of solid tumors (e.g. carcinomas, sarcomas) and lymphomas for therapeutic purposes.

Concepts.definition: Marked or discolored by foreign material.

A biopsy involving the removal of a core tissue containing bone spicules and hematopoietic elements embedded in the marrow stroma.  This procedure is done in the hip area mainly for the diagnosis and evaluation of neoplastic and non-neoplastic hematopoietic disorders (e.g. anemias, leukemias, lymphomas) and the evaluation of the spread of solid tumors (e.g. carcinomas, sarcomas) and lymphomas for therapeutic purposes.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Formaldehyde Fixed Specimen Paraffin Embedded Tissue Core

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Formaldehyde Fixed Specimen Paraffin Embedded Tissue Core
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A colorless poisonous gas synthesized by the oxidation of methanol and used as an antiseptic, disinfectant, histologic fixative, and general-purpose chemical reagent for laboratory applications. Formaldehyde is readily soluble in water and is commonly distributed as a 37% solution in water; formalin, a 10% solution of formaldehyde in water, is used as a disinfectant and to preserve biological specimens. Environmentally, formaldehyde may be found in the atmosphere, smoke from fires, automobile exhaust and cigarette smoke. Small amounts are produced during normal metabolic processes in most organisms, including humans.: Tissue which is preserved in a fixative solution, usually formalin.: Tissue that is preserved and embedded in paraffin.: The center of an object; indispensable

Concepts.definition: A colorless poisonous gas synthesized by the oxidation of methanol and used as an antiseptic, disinfectant, histologic fixative, and general-purpose chemical reagent for laboratory applications. Formaldehyde is readily soluble in water and is commonly distributed as a 37% solution in water; formalin, a 10% solution of formaldehyde in water, is used as a disinfectant and to preserve biological specimens. Environmentally, formaldehyde may be found in the atmosphere, smoke from fires, automobile exhaust and cigarette smoke. Small amounts are produced during normal metabolic processes in most organisms, including humans.
Tissue which is preserved in a fixative solution, usually formalin.
Tissue that is preserved and embedded in paraffin.
The center of an object; indispensable

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Formaldehyde Fixed Specimen Paraffin Embedded Tissue Tissue Scroll

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Formaldehyde Fixed Specimen Paraffin Embedded Tissue Tissue Scroll
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A colorless poisonous gas synthesized by the oxidation of methanol and used as an antiseptic, disinfectant, histologic fixative, and general-purpose chemical reagent for laboratory applications. Formaldehyde is readily soluble in water and is commonly distributed as a 37% solution in water; formalin, a 10% solution of formaldehyde in water, is used as a disinfectant and to preserve biological specimens. Environmentally, formaldehyde may be found in the atmosphere, smoke from fires, automobile exhaust and cigarette smoke. Small amounts are produced during normal metabolic processes in most organisms, including humans.: Tissue which is preserved in a fixative solution, usually formalin.: Tissue that is preserved and embedded in paraffin.: A piece of tissue cut on a microtome so that it rolls up on itself, giving it an appearance similar to a paper scroll.

A piece of tissue cut on a microtome so that it rolls up on itself, giving it an appearance similar to a paper scroll.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The smallest units of living structure capable of independent existence, composed of a membrane-enclosed mass of protoplasm and containing a nucleus or nucleoid.: Blocks; refers to preserved specimens embedded in support material.

Concepts.definition: The smallest units of living structure capable of independent existence, composed of a membrane-enclosed mass of protoplasm and containing a nucleus or nucleoid.
Refers to preserved specimens embedded in support material.  These are typically cut into thin slices for microscopic examination, with or without an enhancement such as staining.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Optimal Cutting Temperature Compound Bone Marrow Core Biopsy

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Optimal Cutting Temperature Compound Bone Marrow Core Biopsy
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A solution of water soluble glycols and resins that provide a specimen support matrix for cryostat sectioning at temperatures of -10 degrees C and below.: The tissue occupying the spaces of bone. It consists of blood vessel sinuses and a network of hematopoietic cells which give rise to the red cells, white cells, and megakaryocytes.: The removal of a tissue sample using a needle with a relatively large diameter, for microscopic examination.

Concepts.definition: A solution of water soluble glycols and resins that provide a specimen support matrix for cryostat sectioning at temperatures of -10 degrees C and below.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Optimal Cutting Temperature Compound Embedding Tissue

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Optimal Cutting Temperature Compound Embedding Tissue
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A solution of water soluble glycols and resins that provide a specimen support matrix for cryostat sectioning at temperatures of -10 degrees C and below.: To surround an object with a firm chemical substance such as wax or resin, in order to perform cutting of thin sections for microscopic examination.: An anatomical structure consisting of similarly specialized cells and intercellular matrix, aggregated according to genetically determined spatial relationships, performing a specific function.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The collection of cells from the inside of a person's cheek using a swab collection device.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A liquid tissue; its major function is to transport oxygen throughout the body. It also supplies the tissues with nutrients, removes waste products, and contains various components of the immune system defending the body against infection. Several hormones also travel in the blood.

Concepts.definition: A liquid tissue; its major function is to transport oxygen throughout the body. It also supplies the tissues with nutrients, removes waste products, and contains various components of the immune system defending the body against infection. Several hormones also travel in the blood.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The tissue occupying the spaces of bone. It consists of blood vessel sinuses and a network of hematopoietic cells which give rise to the red cells, white cells, and megakaryocytes.

Concepts.definition: The tissue occupying the spaces of bone. It consists of blood vessel sinuses and a network of hematopoietic cells which give rise to the red cells, white cells, and megakaryocytes.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Concept annotation added for UPitt/TCGA.  Ylu, 02/03/2015.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Single-stranded long chain of nucleotides containing ribose. It is the end product of DNA transcription by the enzyme RNA polymerase. It is essential in protein synthesis.

Concepts.definition: Single-stranded long chain of nucleotides containing ribose. It is the end product of DNA transcription by the enzyme RNA polymerase. It is essential in protein synthesis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A colorless poisonous gas synthesized by the oxidation of methanol and used as an antiseptic, disinfectant, histologic fixative, and general-purpose chemical reagent for laboratory applications. Formaldehyde is readily soluble in water and is commonly distributed as a 37% solution in water; formalin, a 10% solution of formaldehyde in water, is used as a disinfectant and to preserve biological specimens. Environmentally, formaldehyde may be found in the atmosphere, smoke from fires, automobile exhaust and cigarette smoke. Small amounts are produced during normal metabolic processes in most organisms, including humans._Tissue which is preserved in a fixative solution, usually formalin.

Tissue which is preserved in a fixative solution, usually formalin.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A long linear double-stranded polymer formed from nucleotides attached to a deoxyribose backbone and found in the nucleus of a cell; associated with the transmission of genetic information.

Concepts.definition: A long linear double-stranded polymer formed from nucleotides attached to a deoxyribose backbone and found in the nucleus of a cell; associated with the transmission of genetic information.

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Unstained Specimen Bone Marrow Aspirate Slide Device Component

It consists of blood vessel sinuses and a network of hematopoietic cells which give rise to the red cells, white cells, and megakaryocytes.: Fluid withdrawn from a lump, often a cyst, or a nipple.: A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Be specific about something; define clearly.: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Be specific about something; define clearly.
Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The watery fluid in the mouth made by the salivary glands. Saliva moistens food to help digestion and it helps protect the mouth against infections.

Concepts.definition: The watery fluid in the mouth made by the salivary glands. Saliva moistens food to help digestion and it helps protect the mouth against infections.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The fluid that is excreted by the kidneys.  It is stored in the bladder and discharged through the urethra.

Concepts.definition: The fluid that is excreted by the kidneys.  It is stored in the bladder and discharged through the urethra.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Stained Appearance Blood Smear Slide Device Component

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Stained Appearance Blood Smear Slide Device Component
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Marked or discolored by foreign material.: A sample of blood applied in a thin film to a microscope slide for study under a microscope.: A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study.

Concepts.definition: Marked or discolored by foreign material.
A sample of blood applied in a thin film to a microscope slide for study under a microscope.
A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Unstained Specimen Blood Smear Slide Device Component

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A specimen that is mounted for microscopic study but without preparation methods which use dyes, reagents or other materials to produce coloration in tissues or microorganisms for microscopic examination.: A sample of blood applied in a thin film to a microscope slide for study under a microscope.: A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study.

A sample of blood applied in a thin film to a microscope slide for study under a microscope.
A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The clear portion of the blood that remains after the removal of the blood cells and the clotting proteins.

Concepts.definition: The clear portion of the blood that remains after the removal of the blood cells and the clotting proteins.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Plasma is the fluid (noncellular) portion of the circulating blood, as distinguished from the serum that is the fluid portion of the blood obtained by removal of the fibrin clot and blood cells after coagulation.

Concepts.definition: Plasma is the fluid (noncellular) portion of the circulating blood, as distinguished from the serum that is the fluid portion of the blood obtained by removal of the fibrin clot and blood cells after coagulation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The middle layer of an anticoagulated blood specimen following separation by centrifugation. It contains most of the white blood cells and platelets.

Concepts.definition: The middle layer of an anticoagulated blood specimen following separation by centrifugation. It contains most of the white blood cells and platelets.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A centrifugation procedure that utilizes a density-gradient medium to separate mononuclear and polymorphonuclear leukocytes from other formed elements in the blood.

Concepts.definition: A centrifugation procedure that utilizes a density-gradient medium to separate mononuclear and polymorphonuclear leukocytes from other formed elements in the blood.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Disruption and destruction of the white blood cell membrane.

Concepts.definition: Disruption and destruction of the white blood cell membrane.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Marked or discolored by foreign material.: A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study.

Concepts.definition: Marked or discolored by foreign material.
A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The small amount of fluid that is generated in the abdominal cavity to lubricate the peritoneum.

Concepts.definition: The small amount of fluid that is generated in the abdominal cavity to lubricate the peritoneum.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A specimen that has been subjected to and immobilized by severe cold.: On the inside; contained in.: A substance holding another substance in solution or suspension.

Concepts.definition: A specimen that has been subjected to and immobilized by severe cold.
On the inside; contained in.
A substance holding another substance in solution or suspension.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The fluid that is contained within the brain ventricles, the subarachnoid space and the central canal of the spinal cord.

Concepts.definition: The fluid that is contained within the brain ventricles, the subarachnoid space and the central canal of the spinal cord.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Single-stranded complementary DNA synthesized from an RNA template by the action of RNA-dependent DNA polymerase. cDNA (i.e., complementary DNA, not circular DNA, not C-DNA) is used in a variety of molecular cloning experiments as well as serving as a specific hybridization probe.

Concepts.definition: Single-stranded DNA that is complementary to messenger RNA or DNA that has been synthesized from messenger RNA by reverse transcriptase.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The material discharged from the bowel during defecation.  It consists of undigested food, intestinal mucus, epithelial cells, and bacteria.

Concepts.definition: The material discharged from the bowel during defecation.  It consists of undigested food, intestinal mucus, epithelial cells, and bacteria.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The fluid that is ordinarily present in the pleural space. It allows for normal movement of the lungs during respiration.

Concepts.definition: The fluid that is ordinarily present in the pleural space. It allows for normal movement of the lungs during respiration.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: attributes of a patient's laboratory sample, including the source, condition, and fixative.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
